The song was recorded with John and Paul using the same microphone, creating a unique harmony, each singing a slightly different melody. Both were considered as “the main melody”.
Baby’s in black and I’m feeling blue

The song followed another “downer” song by John Lennon – “I’m a Loser”, making some believe that he was in a down mood. More likely, it was part of the transition Paul and John were undergoing to writing songs with deeper meaning, more reflective and poetic.

So while the song was written after Sutcliffe had died, the writer (probably John Lennon), mixes his past infatuation with the girl in black with his mourning of his ex bass player.
I think of her, but she thinks only of him
Apparently, more than one of Stuart Sutcliffe’s fellow Beatles were infatuated with Astrid Kirchherr, whom they met at a Hamburg club where they performed in 1960 – the Kaiserkeller.

Stuart Sutcliffe passed away in April 1962, less than a year after he quit the Beatles to pursue painting.

The song is presumably about the mourning of ex-Beatle Stuart Sutcliffe who died from apparent aneurysm in 1962 in Germany, being mourned by his girlfriend, Astrid Kirshner.
Baby’s in black and I’m feeling blue
This color word play was used in many songs, as in Los Bravos 1966 hit Black is Black.
